body_html:
Here's a suggestion for now as a smoke test:

  1. create inputs with np.random (use a seed) and use a non-random
    initializer for the variables
  2. create a small ESA cell and run it forward a few time steps & save to
    file the output & final state numbers
  3. write your test to ensure that the same random seeds & deterministic
    initializer lead to the exact same output as you had before (use
    self.assertAllClose with the tensor values you saved from step #2)

this will ensure that future changes to ESA cell do not break its numeric
behavior.

On Wed, Aug 3, 2016 at 1:53 PM, Michele Colombo notifications@github.com
wrote:

Moved to tf.contrib. As soon as I can I'll improve the doc (sorry but I'm
doing this in the spare time after work).
I've written no unit testing, I just tested it on MackeyGlass dataset. I'm
not sure about how to write effective unit testing since it's mostly based
on randomness, however if it's needed I can try to write something.

—

body:
Here's a suggestion for now as a smoke test:
1. create inputs with np.random (use a seed) and use a non-random
   initializer for the variables
2. create a small ESA cell and run it forward a few time steps & save to
   file the output & final state numbers
3. write your test to ensure that the same random seeds & deterministic
   initializer lead to the exact same output as you had before (use
   self.assertAllClose with the tensor values you saved from step #2)

this will ensure that future changes to ESA cell do not break its numeric
behavior.

wrote:

> Moved to tf.contrib. As soon as I can I'll improve the doc (sorry but I'm
> doing this in the spare time after work).
> I've written no unit testing, I just tested it on MackeyGlass dataset. I'm
> not sure about how to write effective unit testing since it's mostly based
> on randomness, however if it's needed I can try to write something.
